articles.content:
Hundreds of Ancient Roman Blade Sharpeners Emerge From a Riverbank in England, Revealing the Ruins of a 2,000-Year-Old Whetstone Factory
Archaeologists think the newly discovered artifacts remained at the production site because they were deemed unusable. Large numbers of completed whetstones may have supplied other parts of the Roman Empire
More than 800 whetstones have been discovered on a riverbank in northern England. Experts say there could be hundreds or thousands more buried at the same site, which they’re describing as a nearly 2,000-year-old Roman industrial hub.
Archaeologist Gary Bankhead, an honorary fellow at England’s Durham University, tells the Guardian’s Mark Brown that previously, only about 250 whetstones have ever been found in the British Isles.
“So for us to suddenly find at least 800 and very likely many hundreds if not thousands more … it is staggering,” Bankhead adds.
Bankhead is also the president of the Vedra Hylton Community Association (VHCA), which led the six-month excavation. The group was assisted by researchers from Durham University’s archaeology department. The whetstones, or stone bars used to sharpen blades, were unearthed by the River Wear near the hamlet of Offerton, near the city of Sunderland.
VHCA volunteer Allyson Timm, the first person to find the whetstones, initially called them “Mars Bar stones” because they were shaped like the rectangular candy bar, she tells BBC News’ Jonny Manning and Jim Scott. “I actually found the first ones over the opposite side of the river and didn’t have a clue what they were,” she adds.
Archaeologists learned that the whetstones were Roman by analyzing the layer of sediment in which they were found, according to a statement from the university. Optically stimulated luminescence testing, which measures when a mineral was last exposed to sunlight, indicated the whetstones had been buried between 104 and 238 C.E. The dates fall firmly within Britain’s Roman period.
Quick fact: When was Britain’s Roman period?
- The Romans occupied Britain, which became the Roman province of Britannia, between the first and fifth centuries C.E.
- The province was guarded by Hadrian’s Wall, which stretched across 73 miles.
Whetstones were common throughout the Roman Empire. Used to sharpen bladed tools and weapons, “every soldier would have needed to use one,” per the Guardian. Researchers think the Offerton site was a whetstone factory, explaining that Romans may have quarried sandstone from the river’s northern bank, brought it to the flatter southern bank and cut it into small bars.
The team also unearthed five stone anchors. In 2022, six anchors had been found at a nearby site, and the new discoveries bring the total to 11, “the largest number of stone anchors ever found at any northern European river site to date,” per the statement. These anchors were probably used by boats transporting sandstone across the river.
Bankhead tells the Guardian that the factory’s location was likely strategic. Finished whetstones would have been transported to the coast, where they were loaded onto seafaring ships and carried to other isles and continental Europe. He adds that the surviving whetstones are damaged.
“We’ve found the broken ones, the off-cuts,” Bankhead tells the Guardian. “The second it fractures, it’s useless—it can’t be used—which is why they remain there.”
Given the number of discarded stones at Offerton, Bankhead wonders how many completed whetstones left the site, according to the Northern Echo’s Andrew White. Perhaps there were enough to supply the entire Roman Empire, he tells the publication.
This whetstone production site was the largest in Britain “without a shadow of a doubt,” says Bankhead to BBC News. “It’s probably the largest number of whetstones found in the entire northwest of Europe. … So it’s a significant location, hidden in plain sight.”
This discovery presents vital evidence of the Romans’ presence in Sunderland. Though the city is only about ten miles south of Hadrian’s Wall, few archaeological artifacts had been found in the past.
“With the confirmation that these whetstones are Roman, this site has the potential to make a significant addition to our understanding of manufacturing and industry in Roman Britain, particularly in the militarized north of the province,” says Eleri Cousins, an archaeologist at Durham University, in a statement.
Researchers found more than whetstones and anchors at the Offerton site. They also unearthed the remains of a post-medieval wooden jetty and an earlier stone jetty, chisels and stone splitters, a Tudor-era leather shoe, iron and stone cannonballs, and lead shot dating to the English Civil Wars.
In recent centuries, “ships, coal, pottery, glass and cars” have all been produced on the banks of the River Wear, Michael Mordey, leader of the Sunderland City Council, says in the statement. Collectively, the new finds stretch back the known timeline of human activity at Offerton by more than 1,800 years.
“This shines a whole new light on the role Sunderland may have played in the Roman Empire, presenting an exciting opportunity to learn new things from our rich historical past,” Mordey says. “This has been a remarkable effort by all involved, and I’m sure I speak for the entire city when I say we can’t wait to find out more about what this research reveals.”

A Cow Named Veronika Can Scratch Her Back With a Broom. Watch the Video That Scientists Are Calling the First Documented Evidence of Cattle Using Tools
The pet cow’s tool use challenges long-held assumptions about bovine intelligence
Around ten years ago, an organic farmer and baker in a small Austrian town noticed that his pet cow would use sticks to scratch herself. The cow, named Veronika, also appeared to refine her technique over the years. Her behavior is the first documented instance of tool use in a cow, according to a new study.
When Alice Auersperg, a cognitive biologist at the University of Veterinary Medicine Vienna and author of the study, saw footage of Veronika, she went to investigate in person. Auersperg and her colleague Antonio Osuna-Mascaró drove to Nötsch im Gailtal, a picturesque town “straight out of The Sound of Music,” Osuna-Mascaró tells Ian Sample at The Guardian.
“Veronika is very friendly,” says Osuna-Mascaró, who spent two weeks observing the cow, to Kate Wong at Scientific American. “She also has a close bond with Witgar,” her owner. “Not only does Witgar prepare and sell bread, he also distributes it around the area. It was interesting to see Veronika watching every passing car with interest and trying to guess if the driver was Witgar,” he says to the outlet. “If she thought it was him, she would moo with all her might.”
The two researchers observed how Veronika used a deck-cleaning broom over a series of 70 trials last summer. The definition of tool use is strict—an animal must intentionally use an object in order to achieve a specific goal.
Veronika consistently used the broom as a tool, using her tongue to get a grip on the broom’s handle and maneuver it to scratch different parts of her body. The findings were published in the journal Current Biology on January 19.Christian Nawroth, a farm animal cognition researcher at the Research Institute for Farm Animal Biology in Germany who was not involved in the work, tells Emily Anthes at the New York Times that the study shows a clear-cut case of animal tool use. “It looks very convincing,” he says.
The researchers had assumed that Veronika would mainly use the broom’s bristled end to scratch herself, but she occasionally flipped it around to reach the softer parts of her body. At first, the researchers thought it was a mistake. “But after a while we started to observe a pattern: Veronika indeed had a preference for using the broom end, but when she used the handle end she was doing so in a meaningful way,” says Osuna-Mascaró to The Guardian.
So far, the ability to use a single tool for multiple purposes has only been seen in chimpanzees. “It’s totally unexpected to see this in cattle,” Auersperg tells David Grimm at Science.
Quick fact: Tool use in seabirds
- In 2019, a team of researchers published a study on the first documented case of a seabird using tools—a puffin scratching its feathers with a twig.
The researchers don’t think Veronika is an unusually smart cow. Rather, her upbringing may have enabled her to pick up the skill. Osuna-Mascaró explains to Scientific American that Veronika’s human family provided “the special conditions that enabled Veronika to express herself.” Her owner gave her sticks and rakes that she could learn to manipulate, something most cows don’t have access to.
The researchers hope their work will inspire other scientists to look at species that may have been overlooked, such as other farm animals. There have been anecdotal reports of tool use in goats and water buffalo, says Rob Shumaker, an evolutionary biologist who was not involved in the study, on NPR's All Things Considered.
“We haven’t been looking well enough at these animals,” Auersperg says to the New York Times. “Perhaps the absurd thing was not the absurdity of a cow using tools, but the absurdity of us never thinking that a cow might be intelligent.”

This Dinosaur May Have Used Its Strange Clawed Hands to Pilfer and Pierce Eggs
A fresh analysis of a fossil found almost 50 years ago reveals a newly described genus named for its “manipulating claw”
Millions of years ago, a tiny dinosaur in what’s now Mongolia may have used its unique claws to steal meals in the dead of night.
A fresh analysis of a roughly 67-million-year-old fossil—a nearly complete spiky forearm, including a hooked claw, along with other bones—uncovered almost 50 years ago hints that the owner specialized in pilfering and piercing eggs. What’s more, the study authors suggest that this dinosaur represents a newly described genus and species, Manipulonyx reshetovi, named for its “manipulating claw” and the paleontologist who discovered the specimen.
The findings were published in December in the journal Proceedings of the Zoological Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences.
“It’s a spectacular arm,” says Denver Fowler, a paleontologist at the Badlands Dinosaur Museum who was not involved with the study, to Taylor Mitchell Brown at Science News. “The fact that this is the most complete arm of these already bizarre-looking dinosaurs is exceptional; their arms were even weirder than we thought.”
A Russian paleontologist found the skeletal remains in Mongolia’s Gobi Desert in 1979. The fossil belongs to a family of feathered, two-legged dinosaurs called alvarezsaurids—thought to be about 20 to 80 inches long—which are known for their stubby arms that had one long claw and two tiny side digits.
Did you know? A famous bonebed
M. reshetovi’s remains were found in the Nemegt Formation, a site well-known for housing fossils from several dinosaur species—including tyrannosaurids—that were alive at the end of the Cretaceous period, which concluded with the famous asteroid strike about 66 million years ago.
Past research suggested that alvarezsaurids used their forelimbs to dig into ant and termite colonies, like anteaters. But in 2018, a team of Chinese researchers proposed that the dinosaurs instead relied on their odd appendages to steal eggs from oviraptorids, a family of bird-like dinosaurs, after finding an alvarezsaurid fossil close to shell fragments. Similarly, M. reshetovi’s museum label noted that fossilized eggshells were found near the remains.
For the new analysis, researchers CT-scanned the skeletal remains to create digital 3D versions of them. The reconstructions revealed differences from other alvarezsaurids, indicating the fossils came from a previously undescribed species. Moreover, the scans hinted that the bones’ owner probably didn’t use its diminutive arms to unearth insect homes.
“Such a limb would have been completely unsuitable for destroying termite mounds,” study co-author Alexey Lopatin, a paleontologist at the Russian Academy of Sciences, tells Science News. “The thin, piercing claw would have broken off in the process, and the fragile vestigial fingers and spikes would have been damaged.”
The study authors suggest that M. reshetovi used their arm spikes, likely covered in keratin—the substance that makes up fingernails—and teensy side fingers to grasp a slippery egg. Then, the dinosaur would use its long claw to puncture the eggshell.
Stephen Brusatte, a paleontologist at the University of Edinburgh in Scotland who was not involved in the study, tells the New York Times’ Jack Tamisea that the authors’ egg-snatching hypothesis is plausible. However, the dinosaurs may have had a different use for their strange limbs, which future research might uncover.
“All I’m confident in saying is that they weren’t using these arms and hands to fly or swim,” Brusatte says. “Beyond that, let your imaginations run wild.”

These Baffling Bone Artifacts Discovered by an Amateur Archaeologist May Be the World’s Oldest Whale Harpoons
After revisiting items from a Brazilian museum, researchers think humans may have been hunting whales 5,000 years ago, a millennium earlier than previously thought
Researchers in Brazil think they may have discovered the earliest known evidence of whaling. According to a recent study published in the journal Nature Communications, harpoons found in museum storage may have been used to hunt whales roughly 5,000 years ago.
If the researchers’ conclusions are correct, whale hunting in South America began a millennium earlier than experts previously thought, per a statement from the Autonomous University of Barcelona.
The artifacts, which are made from whale bone, were found in refuse piles along Babitonga Bay in southern Brazil. Whale bones have been found at early South American sites before, but scientists had assumed that they’d been collected from beached whales or carcasses that washed up on shore. “The consensus was [that] the people living along the Brazilian coast were just collecting animals that were stranded, because no one had ever found large harpoons before,” study co-author André Carlo Colonese, an archaeologist at the Autonomous University of Barcelona, tells Science’s Andrew Curry.
The area around Babitonga Bay was once home to hundreds of sambaquis, which were large piles of shells, bones and fish remains. Between the 1940s and 1960s, as developers disassembled the sambaquis, amateur archaeologist Guilherme Tiburtius recovered boxes of artifacts and bones from the piles. Eventually, some 9,000 of these items ended up in the local Museu Arqueológico de Sambaqui de Joinville.
Many years later, Colonese visited the museum alongside lead author Krista McGrath, a molecular archaeologist at the Autonomous University of Barcelona, and co-author Tatiane Andaluzia, an archaeologist at Brazil’s Federal University of Parana. They were looking for evidence of prehistoric ocean fishing in Brazil.
“The curators went in back and brought out dusty boxes with whale bone artifacts inside,” Colonese tells Science. “The moment they took them out, I said, ‘Guys, these are harpoons.’”
Quick fact: What is a harpoon?
These tools are barbed spears used to hunt sea animals such as whales, swordfish, sharks and tuna.
The researchers were looking at long pieces of bone that resembled whale hunting tools found at more recent South American sites. They wondered whether these tools had been used to hunt whales, too.
The team examined hundreds of marine bones and bone tools that came from the sambaquis of Babitonga Bay using a combination of zooarchaeology, typological analysis and molecular techniques, per the statement. The analysis found the bones came from southern right whales, humpback whales, blue whales, sei whales, sperm whales and dolphins.
“The southern right whale is very coastal. They’re slow swimmers, and they float after they’re struck by harpoons and die,” says Youri van den Hurk, an archaeologist at the University of Bergen in Norway who wasn’t involved in the research, to Science. “That makes it easy for these hunters to drag them to shore.”
As the researchers write, “There is consensus that the systematic pursuit of large whales is a more recent cultural phenomenon.” However, rock art discovered in Korea and Scandinavia suggests that humans may have been hunting whales on a smaller scale up to 6,000 years ago.
According to the museum’s records, some of the sambaquis of Babitonga Bay were burial places, as well as refuse piles. Harpoons and other carved whale bones were found next to human skeletons in the mounds, suggesting that the dangerous act of whale hunting, which would have provided communities with numerous resources, may have been culturally significant.
“You can imagine a big feast where everyone eats a lot of meat and blubber, and at the same time they collect oil,” Colonese tells National Geographic’s Tom Metcalfe. “You can store the oil for a very long time, you can use it as fuel and then you have all the bones. … A whale is very valuable.”
The study sheds new light on the region’s culture, which historians already knew was inextricably linked to marine life and resources. Colonese says in the statement that the research “represents a paradigm shift—we can now view these groups not only as shellfish collectors and fishers, but also as whalers.”
Archaeologist Gregory Monks, an emeritus archaeologist at Canada’s University of Manitoba, tells Science that the study is convincing, but direct evidence of a harpoon attack would have made it stronger.
“They have what could be evidence of active whaling very early—earlier than it’s ever been demonstrated in the Northern Hemisphere,” says Monks, who wasn’t involved in the research. “The evidence is very suggestive, and they’re probably right. But none of the bones had any puncture wounds or damage from harpoon thrusts. Where’s the smoking harpoon?”
